body.p: This document is targeted at developers, that are persons who want to contribute to the Community Z Tools project.

section.title: General remarks
section.p: Make yourself familiar with the project by following the announcements and discussions on czt-devel.

When you want to contribute code, it is best to start from the sources from CVS. See the
documentation about CVS on sourceforge
for more information about how to access the CZT repository. If you are not yet a member of the CZT project, you may contribute patches via the
czt page on sourceforge.
If you are already a member, you should have write access to (parts of) the CVS repository.

ul.li: Make yourself familiar with CVS, for instance by reading The CVS Book
Before commiting changes, make sure that your working directory is in sync with the main CVS repository by calling cvs update
Check-in often to help other developers keep their code in sync with your code, but make sure that the software is compiling and running properly

section.title: Subproject Structure
section.p: Each subproject of CZT is located in its own subdirectory. The file and directory structure within this directory should be as follows:

ul.li: README.txt --- the README file containing information about the subproject (prerequisites, how to build it, how to run it, etc.)
build.xml --- the ant build file
build --- a temporary build directory
doc --- the directory where the documentation lives
examples --- the directory where examples live
src --- the directory where the source code live
lib --- the directory where application-specific library files live
tests --- the directory where the tests live

section.title: Java style guidelines
section.p: In order to make it easier for other developers to read your Java source code, please follow the Java Programming Style Guidelines from Geotechnical Software Services. You can use the following emacs settings to ensure that your editor uses the correct indentation.

Use checkstyle to check whether your code follows those guidelines (there is a checkstyle settings file in <CZT_HOME>/devtools/checkstyle.xml). Have a look at the example build file to see how you can provide a checkstyle ant target.

section.title: Ant build files
section.p:
Within the CZT project,
Ant
is used as build tool. Ant build files are usually called build.xml and should provide the following targets:

ul.li: all --- build the jar file(s) and the documentation
api --- build the API documentation
checkstyle --- checks the source code whether it follows the coding conventions
clean --- clean up
compile --- compile the sources
doc --- build all the documentation
install --- build the jar files and copy it into the <CZT_HOME>/lib directory
run --- run the application
test --- compile and run the tests

section.p: Properties that may be set by the user should be set in czt.properties, which is located in <CZT_HOME>, the root of the CZT directory tree.
To get started, you can use an example build file for the imaginary CZT subproject Foo.
